repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: No way to customize completion order across multiple servers.

Solution: Add `sort` function to `vim.lsp.completion.enable()` options
for custom sorting logic.

comment_data.body: I can't find any mention in the LSP spec that `sortText` is case-insensitive. It would be helpful to clarify why this behavior is required.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -274,6 +274,50 @@ local function match_item_by_value(value, prefix)
   return vim.startswith(value, prefix)
 end
 
+--- Compare two completion items according priority: sortText > label > kind
+---
+--- @param a table completion item with user_data
+--- @param b table completion item with user_data
+--- @return boolean
+local function compare_completion_items(a, b)
+  ---@type lsp.CompletionItem
+  local item_a = vim.tbl_get(a, 'user_data', 'nvim', 'lsp', 'completion_item')
+  ---@type lsp.CompletionItem
+  local item_b = vim.tbl_get(b, 'user_data', 'nvim', 'lsp', 'completion_item')
+  if not item_a then
+    return false
+  end
+  if not item_b then
+    return true
+  end
+
+  -- 1. Compare by sortText
+  if item_a.sortText and item_b.sortText then
+    local sort_a_lower = item_a.sortText:lower()

comment_data.body: The `label` field is required, so why does it need a fallback?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -274,6 +274,50 @@ local function match_item_by_value(value, prefix)
   return vim.startswith(value, prefix)
 end
 
+--- Compare two completion items according priority: sortText > label > kind
+---
+--- @param a table completion item with user_data
+--- @param b table completion item with user_data
+--- @return boolean
+local function compare_completion_items(a, b)
+  ---@type lsp.CompletionItem
+  local item_a = vim.tbl_get(a, 'user_data', 'nvim', 'lsp', 'completion_item')
+  ---@type lsp.CompletionItem
+  local item_b = vim.tbl_get(b, 'user_data', 'nvim', 'lsp', 'completion_item')
+  if not item_a then
+    return false
+  end
+  if not item_b then
+    return true
+  end
+
+  -- 1. Compare by sortText
+  if item_a.sortText and item_b.sortText then
+    local sort_a_lower = item_a.sortText:lower()
+    local sort_b_lower = item_b.sortText:lower()
+    if sort_a_lower ~= sort_b_lower then
+      return sort_a_lower < sort_b_lower
+    end
+  end
+
+  -- 2. Compare by label
+  local label_a = type(item_a.label) == 'string' and item_a.label or (item_a.label and item_a.label)
+  local label_b = type(item_b.label) == 'string' and item_b.label or (item_b.label and item_b.label)
+
+  if not label_a then
+    return false
+  end
+  if not label_b then
+    return true
+  end
+  if label_a ~= label_b then
+    return label_a < label_b
+  end
+
+  -- 3. Compare by kind
+  return (item_a.kind or 0) < (item_b.kind or 0)

comment_data.body:
> Implement proper comparison: sortText (case-insensitive, only when both present) > label > kind

Could you please clarify why `sortText` should only be compared when both items have it?

The spec says: 
```
/**
 * A string that should be used when comparing this item
 * with other items. When omitted, the label is used
 * as the sort text for this item.
 */
sortText?: string;
```

The phrase "when comparing this item with other items" seems to imply that the comparison value for the other item may not necessarily be `sortText`. The field priorities apply within a single item, not across items.

comment_data.body:
I'd rather not use the vsc*de LSP implementation as a reference.. Even in this case, comparing `sortText` values that way violates the existing spec IMO.

I can't think of a situation where `label`s would be identical, but if there's an example where falling back to `kind` improves sorting, it would be better to propose that behavior to the spec rather than silently spread across client implementations without the server's developers being aware of it. The same applies to case-insensitiveness.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -274,6 +274,50 @@ local function match_item_by_value(value, prefix)
   return vim.startswith(value, prefix)
 end
 
+--- Compare two completion items according priority: sortText > label > kind

+--- @param a table completion item with user_data
+--- @param b table completion item with user_data
+--- @return boolean

+  local item_a = vim.tbl_get(a, 'user_data', 'nvim', 'lsp', 'completion_item')
+  ---@type lsp.CompletionItem

+  if not item_a then

+  end

+  -- 1. Compare by sortText
+  if item_a.sortText and item_b.sortText then

comment_data.body: In most cases, I think itâ€™s fine to just refer to VSCodeâ€™s general implementation. The initial design of LSP was probably also intended for it. I donâ€™t have any specific ideas about the comparison model. But referencing VSCode shouldnâ€™t be a problem. The main thing here is to fix the sorting to be consistent. I donâ€™t want certain results, like custom LSP completion words, to always appear at the top ðŸ˜®â€ðŸ’¨

comment_data.body:
> Even in this case, comparing sortText values that way violates the existing spec IMO.

My interpretation is the same. The linked vscode doesn't appear to follow the specification.

Neovim policy so far is to strictly stick to the spec and if the spec is too limiting or leading to bad results in some cases, the policy is to create an issue in the spec repo to ask for clarification or extend the spec.


Also to add: Keep in mind that sortText can contain arbitrary values that a server can choose to force a certain ordering on the client side. This likely won't be comparable across language servers. 

For example, if one server uses uses a int formatted with 4 digits for odering (`"0001"`, `"0002"`) and another 3 digits, with alphanumeric sort you'll get `["0001","0002","001","002"]`

I'm not opposed to merging the results first - just want to point out that in many cases this won't improve the ordering either.

(Maybe a way out would be to add a `sort` function as part of `lsp.completion.enable`, similar to the existing `convert` function, for customization)

 end

comment_data.body:
> (Maybe a way out would be to add a sort function as part of lsp.completion.enable, similar to the existing convert function, for customization)

sure give it a try .

> I'm not opposed to merging the results first - just want to point out that in many cases this won't improve the ordering either.

When sort is provided, donâ€™t perform sorting for each server and use `sort` after merge all results. otherwise, keep the current behavior and sort once per server ?

comment_data.body: If this is the comparator should it be called `cmp` (see `:help table.sort()`, `vim.version.cmp()`) rather than `sort` ?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2058,6 +2058,8 @@ enable({enable}, {client_id}, {bufnr}, {opts})
                        `triggerCharacters`.
                      â€¢ {convert}? (`fun(item: lsp.CompletionItem): table`)
                        Transforms an LSP CompletionItem to |complete-items|.
+                     â€¢ {sort}? (`fun(a: table, b: table): boolean`) Comparator

comment_data.body: cmp is also fine doc describes it as a comparator...

comment_regular_data.body:
Needs rebase.

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/36401#discussion_r2540524414 is not a blocker, and mabye `sort` is more intuitive/discoverable even though technically not quite correct.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(lsp): add cmp option to completion.enable()
